p: What It Is: Unity Catalog (UC) is Databricks' unified governance solution for data and AI assets across clouds. It provides a single place to manage access control, auditing, lineage, and data discovery.
Key Problem It Solves: Before UC, Databricks used workspace-level Hive metastore with limited governance capabilities. UC centralizes governance across multiple workspaces and clouds.
Access Control: Fine-grained permissions (catalog, schema, table, column, row levels)
Auditing: Comprehensive audit logs for all data access
Lineage: Automated capture of data flow (table-to-table, column-to-column)
Data Discovery: Search and explore data assets across the organization
Quality Monitoring: Integration with Databricks Lakehouse Monitoring
Interview Question: Why Unity Catalog over Hive Metastore?
Catalog: Logical boundary for environment (prod, dev, staging)
Schema: Logical grouping of related tables (sales, marketing, finance)
Cannot skip levels: Must specify catalog.schema.table, not just catalog.table
Default catalog/schema: Can be set per session to avoid repetition
What It Is: The metastore is the top-level container for Unity Catalog metadata. It stores:
Key Constraint: One metastore per region (not per workspace)
Access Connector for Azure Databricks (managed identity)
Multiple workspaces can be assigned to the same metastore
Workspaces in the same region share the metastore
Enables cross-workspace data sharing and governance
Interview Question: Can you have multiple metastores in one region?
No. One metastore per region is the design constraint.
Workspaces in the region must use that metastore or none at all.
Metastore-level: Default location for all catalogs
Catalog-level: Overrides metastore default for specific catalog
Schema-level: Overrides catalog default for specific schema
If no location specified, uses parent's managed location
Changing managed location does not migrate existing data
Purpose: Define authentication to cloud storage without exposing secrets in table definitions.
Purpose: Map storage credentials to specific storage paths. Enables governed access to external data.
Interview Question: Storage Credential vs External Location?
Storage Credential: Authentication mechanism (HOW to authenticate)
External Location: Specific path + credential (WHERE + HOW)
External Location references a Storage Credential
What It Is: Azure-managed identity that Databricks uses to access ADLS Gen2 without storing credentials.
Create Access Connector in Azure Portal
Grant Access Connector RBAC permissions on ADLS Gen2 (Storage Blob Data Contributor)
Create Storage Credential in UC referencing the Access Connector
Create External Location using the Storage Credential
Access Connector must have proper RBAC on storage account
Common error: "403 Forbidden" due to missing RBAC
Definition: UC manages both metadata and underlying data files. When table is dropped, both metadata and data are deleted.
Storage: Data stored in managed location (metastore/catalog/schema level).
Interview Question: What happens when you DROP a managed table?
Metadata deleted: Table definition removed from metastore
Data deleted: Underlying files deleted from storage
Cannot recover unless you have storage-level backups
Definition: UC manages metadata only. User manages underlying data files. When table is dropped, only metadata is removed.
Interview Question: Why use External Tables?
Data shared across platforms (Databricks, Snowflake, Presto)
What Are Volumes? Storage for non-tabular data (PDFs, images, ML models, binaries) with UC governance.
Definition: UC manages lifecycle and storage. Deleting volume deletes files.
Definition: Points to external storage path. Deleting volume does not delete files.
Volumes: Governed, UC-integrated, recommended for UC-enabled workspaces
DBFS: Legacy, no UC governance, being deprecated
Definition: Virtual table defined by a query. No data stored; query executed each time view is accessed.
User needs SELECT on underlying tables
Cannot be directly written to (read-only from user perspective)
Definition: Pre-computed view where results are stored and incrementally refreshed.
Delta Lake backed: Results stored as Delta table
Incremental refresh: Only processes new data since last refresh
Interview Question: Materialized View vs Table?
Materialized View: Auto-refreshed, lineage-tracked, tied to source query
Refresh may lag behind source data
Table: Manual load, no automatic refresh, no query dependency

l: 04 Data Governance, Lineage, Observability, Lakehouse Federation

p: Mechanism: Use current_user() or is_member() functions in view definition to filter rows.
Interview Question: How does row-level security work?
View evaluates user context at query time
Base table should be restricted; grant access to view only
Mechanism: Create SQL UDF that applies masking logic, use in views or enforce via policies.
Databricks Runtime 13.3+ Feature: Column-level access control via GRANT SELECT(column)(limited preview as of 2025).
System Tables: Unity Catalog maintains audit logs in system tables.
All data access (SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE)
Table-to-table lineage: Which tables are used to create other tables
Column-to-column lineage: Which source columns feed into target columns
Notebook/job lineage: Which notebooks/jobs accessed data
Databricks Data Explorer → Select table → Lineage tab
Visual graph showing upstream and downstream dependencies
Example: If customer_summary.total_spent is derived from orders.amount, UC tracks this relationship.
Interview Question: How is lineage captured?
Parses SQL/DataFrame operations to extract dependencies
Stores lineage metadata in Unity Catalog metastore
Limitation: May not capture lineage from external tools (e.g., dbt, Airflow) unless they use Databricks APIs
Definition: Query external data systems (Snowflake, PostgreSQL, Redshift, MySQL) directly from Databricks without copying data.
Query external system using Spark SQL syntax
Pushdown Optimization: Databricks pushes filters to external system when possible.
Interview Question: When to use Federation vs ETL?
Federation: Real-time queries, small result sets, infrequent access
ETL: Large data volumes, frequent queries, complex transformations

l: 05 Metrics, User Identity, Delta Sharing, Secret Management

p: What Are UC Metrics? Business-defined metrics stored in Unity Catalog. Provides consistent metric definitions across tools (Databricks SQL, BI tools, notebooks).
Single source of truth: Metrics defined once, used everywhere
Governance: UC permissions apply to metrics
BI tool integration: Expose metrics to Tableau, Power BI
Interview Question: UC Metrics vs Materialized Views?
UC Metrics: Business logic layer, consistent definitions, BI integration
Materialized Views: Performance optimization, pre-computed results
Workspace users: Created directly in Databricks
Federated users: Synced from Entra ID (Azure AD), Okta, OneLogin
Recommended Approach: Use identity federation for centralized user management.
Configure SCIM provisioning in Azure Portal
Map Azure AD groups to Databricks groups
What Are Service Principals? Non-human identities for automation (pipelines, jobs, applications).
Interview Question: Users vs Service Principals?
Service Principals: Machine identities, automated workflows
What Is Delta Sharing? Open protocol for secure data sharing. Share Delta tables with external organizations without copying data.
Open source protocol: Works with non-Databricks recipients
Read-only: Recipients can query but not modify data
Audit logs: Track who accessed shared data
Non-Databricks Recipients: Use Delta Sharing connectors (Python, Pandas, PrestoDB, Trino).
Interview Question: Delta Sharing vs API?
Delta Sharing: Standardized, governed, no custom API needed
API: Custom code, harder to govern, more maintenance
Purpose: Store sensitive information (passwords, API keys, tokens) securely. Secrets not exposed in code or notebooks.
Databricks-backed scope: Secrets stored in Databricks control plane
Azure Key Vault-backed scope: Secrets stored in Azure Key Vault (recommended for production)
Create Databricks secret scope linked to Key Vault
Interview Question: Why not hardcode secrets?
Security risk: Secrets exposed in code, version control, logs
Centralized management: Rotate secrets without code changes

l: Q1: How do you migrate from Hive Metastore to Unity Catalog?
p: Enable UC on workspace: Assign metastore to workspace
Create UC catalogs/schemas: Mirror existing Hive database structure
Sync external tables: Use SYNC command or manual CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE
Sync managed tables: Use DEEP CLONE or CREATE TABLE AS SELECT
Update code: Change table references from database.table to catalog.schema.table
Migrate permissions: Recreate GRANT statements in UC
Validate lineage and audit logs: Ensure governance is working

l: Q2: How do you implement multi-region data sharing with UC?
p: Problem: One metastore per region, but need to share data across regions
Recipient queries data via Delta Sharing protocol (no data replication)

l: Q3: What happens if you drop a catalog with existing tables?
p: CASCADE deletes ALL data in managed tables
Use with extreme caution in production

l: Q4: How do you troubleshoot "Permission Denied" errors in UC?
p: Check if user has USE CATALOG and USE SCHEMA permissions
Check if user has SELECT permission on table
For external tables, check if user has access to External Location
For external tables, check if Storage Credential has valid cloud permissions
Check audit logs to see which permission check failed

l: Q5: How do you enforce data retention policies in UC?
p: Table-level: Use Delta table properties delta.deletedFileRetentionDuration
Governance-level: Use UC permissions to restrict DELETE/TRUNCATE
Audit-level: Monitor audit logs for data deletion
Assuming DBFS and Volumes are interchangeable (they're not)
Expecting multi-region metastore (constraint: one per region)
Forgetting USE CATALOG permission when granting SELECT
Lakehouse Federation: Query external systems without ETL
Managed vs External tables: Lifecycle, DROP behavior, use cases
Materialized Views: Incremental refresh, use cases
Metastore architecture: One per region, multi-workspace assignment
Mixing up Storage Credential (auth) and External Location (path + auth)
Not understanding DROP behavior for managed vs external tables
Permissions model: GRANT/REVOKE, object hierarchy, row/column security
Storage Credentials & External Locations: How they work together
Three-level namespace: Understand catalog → schema → table hierarchy
Volumes: Purpose, managed vs external, replacing DBFS
End of Unity Catalog Interview Preparation Notes
Databricks is a cloud-native Data Intelligence Platform that unifies:
on top of Apache Spark + Delta Lake, delivered as a managed service.
Built around open data formats(Parquet, Delta)
Strong focus on end-to-end lifecycle(ingestion → analytics → ML → BI)
Databricks eliminates data duplication between lake + warehouse.
Databricks removed Hadoop’s operational complexity while retaining Spark’s scale.
No governance, no orchestration, no lineage
Built-in jobs, monitoring, security, SQL, MLflow

l: Databricks as a Data Intelligence Platform
p: “Data Intelligence” = Data + AI + Governance + Cost Control
A Lakehouse is an architecture that:
Uses data lakes as the single source of truth
Adds warehouse-like guarantees directly on the lake
Databricks Lakehouse = Delta Lake + Optimized Spark execution
Delta Lake is non-negotiable in interviews.
Delta Lake is the foundation that makes the Lakehouse reliable.
Databricks deploys compute inside your VPC/VNet.
Databricks cannot access your raw data
Data never leaves your cloud account
One job run = one cluster lifecycle
Prefer job clusters for production due to isolation + cost efficiency.
Unity Catalog restricts access modes intentionally.
Prevent developers from creating oversized clusters.
Replaces parts of Spark execution engine
Lower DBU cost for same workload
Photon is not a separate cluster
Photon is not optional at runtime(auto-enabled when supported)
Governance lives at account level, not workspace level.
Confusing control plane with data plane
Treating Databricks as a proprietary warehouse
Context shift (important for interviews) Databricks is moving from imperative Spark pipelines→ declarative, optimized-by-default pipelines. Lakeflow is the umbrella for this evolution.
Lakeflow is Databricks’ unified ingestion + transformation + orchestration framework for data engineering.
Automatically applies incremental processing and optimizations
Lakeflow does not replace Spark— it abstracts execution decisions.
Lakeflow shifts responsibility from developers to the platform.
Tight integration with Jobs & Unity Catalog
Auto Loader is a structured streaming–based ingestion mechanism for cloud object storage.

l: Notification Mode vs Directory Listing Mode

p: Uses cloud-native notifications (SQS, Event Grid, Pub/Sub)
Declarative = define what the table should look like, not how to compute it.
Expectations are data quality rules enforced at write time.
Expectations are enforced before data is committed.
Enzyme is Databricks’ internal optimization engine for incremental processing.
Only affected downstream data is recomputed
Enzyme makes declarative pipelines cost-efficient at scale.

l: 3.6 Data Layout Optimization – Liquid Clustering (🔥 Very High Yield)

p: Liquid Clustering is a dynamic, adaptive data layout optimization for Delta tables.
Liquid Clustering removes the need to design partitions manually.
Not ideal for very small tables
Auto Loader → continuous or triggered Jobs
Treating Lakeflow as a product, not a framework
Writing manual incremental logic when declarative is available
Reply “Proceed to Section 4 (Databricks SQL)” when ready.
What is a Databricks Asset Bundle (DAB)?
A Databricks Asset Bundle is a declarative, version-controlled packaging format that enables Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC) for Databricks. It is a single deployable unit containing:
Databricks resource definitions (jobs, pipelines, clusters, dashboards, etc.)
Environment Portability: Deploy the same code to multiple environments with different configurations
CI/CD Integration: Automate deployments via GitHub Actions, Azure DevOps, or similar systems
Version Control: All assets tracked in Git; no manual UI-based resource creation
Reproducibility: Identical deployments across workspaces; no configuration drift
Single Source of Truth: Git becomes the authoritative state for your Databricks infrastructure
Build instructions for Python wheels, JARs, etc.
Bundle metadata: name(required), git, deployment, cluster_id
databricks.yml is the single source of truth for a bundle. It defines bundle identity, deployment targets, variables, resources, and behavior.
Parameterized values; resolved at deployment time
Path globs to include additional YAML files
Marks DLT pipelines as development: true
resources(target-specific job configurations, cluster sizes, schedules)
Targets are named deployment contexts. Each target can have its own workspace, configuration, and resource overrides.
workspace(host URL, root_path for artifact storage)
Bundle variables are deployment-time parameters injected into resource definitions. They enable parameterized deployments without hardcoding environment-specific values.
Bundle variables are resolved at deployment time (when databricks bundle deploy runs)
Job parameters and notebook widgets are resolved at runtime (when the job executes)
Once deployed, changing a variable requires re-deployment; changing parameters at run-time does NOT reflect the deployment
Sources of Variable Values(in order of precedence)
Variables are referenced using ${var.variable_name} throughout databricks.yml:
Code checked into Git, deployed to workspace
Each resource must have a unique programmatic key within its type:
Optional; usually referenced by job tasks
Orchestrate tasks: notebooks, Python scripts, JARs
Removed resources are deleted from workspace if previously deployed
Resources are Databricks objects managed by the bundle. They are declarative definitions of jobs, pipelines, notebooks, clusters, etc.
Subsequent deployments update existing resource (no duplication)
The key is used internally by the CLI; the name field is what users see in Databricks UI.
A single unit of work (notebook, Python script, JAR, SQL query)
Define execution order and data passing
Global parameters available to all tasks
Input values passed to a task
Jobs define multi-task workflows in Databricks. A job orchestrates execution order, passes data between tasks, and manages retries/alerts.
Task runs on existing cluster or new cluster
Unique identifier within a job; used for dependencies
⚠️ DLT pipelines do NOT use notebook widgets like jobs do. Use:
Pipeline code accesses configuration via Spark:
Pipelines are declarative data transformation frameworks. Unlike jobs (imperative orchestration), pipelines define the desired state of data.
Notebooks are first-class bundle artifacts. They are checked into Git, deployed to the workspace, and versioned as part of the bundle.
By default, DAB syncs all files defined in bundle configuration to the workspace. Fine-tune synchronization:
Files are deployed to a workspace path managed by the bundle:
Pareto Pattern: How Parameters Flow Through the System
include allows you to split databricks.yml across multiple files for modularity.

l: 11. Artifacts: Python Wheels and Build Artifacts
p: Artifacts are built dependencies packaged as part of a bundle (e.g., Python wheels, JAR files).
CI/CD: Use service principal with minimal permissions for the environment it accesses
Databricks CLI reads from ~/.databrickscfg(local) or environment variables:
Local development: Run as your user ( user_name)
Production: Always run as a production service principal
Separate the identity that deploys from the identity that runs:
Staging: Run as a staging service principal
Who runs the deployed job/pipeline (via run_as)
Runs deployed job; not a deployment step
The Databricks CLI is the execution engine for bundle operations.
DAB maintains deployment state to ensure idempotent, repeatable deployments.
Nth deploy with no changes: No Databricks API calls made
Deploy after edit: Only changed resources updated
Remove from YAML, redeploy: Resource deleted from workspace
A bundle resource is uniquely identified by:
Changing any of these is considered a new resource:
Git is Source of Truth: All infrastructure defined in version control; no UI-driven resource creation
Declarative Over Imperative: YAML configuration defines desired state; CLI executes it
Environment Parity: Same code, different configurations via targets
Reproducibility: Deployments are deterministic and repeatable across workspaces
Separation of Concerns: Deployment identity ≠ Execution identity (via run_as)
All variables have values (no missing required vars)
Git branch matches bundle.git.branch(prevents accidental deployments from wrong branch)
Service principal (for run_as) exists and has necessary permissions
Secrets are stored in Databricks Secret Scopes, not hardcoded
CI/CD pipeline uses service principal credentials, not user PATs

l: 17. Practical Mental Model for LLMs and Humans
p: "Can I deploy to both workspaces from one databricks.yml?"

"Why does DAB delete my resource when I remove it from YAML?"
By design. Deployment state tracks what was deployed; removing it from YAML signals deletion intent.
databricks.yml is the control plane: Everything flows from this file; targets, variables, and resources define behavior
If you understand these 5 things, you understand 80% of DAB:
Jobs pass parameters to widgets: Job base_parameters→ notebook dbutils.widgets.get(); DLT pipelines use configuration instead
No. DLT uses pipeline configuration and Spark session configuration, not widgets. Widgets are job/notebook-only.
Resources are idempotent: Deploy 100 times; same result each time
Targets are environment configurations: Same code, different variables and overrides per environment
Variables are deployment-time; jobs run with values from last bundle deploy. Re-deploy to pick up changes.
Variables are deployment-time: Set once during bundle deploy; changing them requires re-deployment
Yes (if bundle is in workspace Git folder). Limited support; CLI is recommended for production.
Yes. Define multiple targets with different workspace.host values; deploy to each separately.
Listed for completeness; less critical for productivity
Dynamic Value References: {{ ERROR }}, {{ ERROR }} for context-aware job parameters
Permissions: permissions section for granular ACLs on bundle resources
Source-Linked Deployments: Dev mode option to reference workspace code instead of synced copies
Binding: databricks bundle bind to associate existing workspace resources with bundle management
Environments: Different cloud providers (AWS, Azure, GCP) supported; configuration differs slightly
MLflow Experiments & Models: Bundles can manage registered models and experiments
Dashboards & SQL Assets: Bundles support AI/BI Dashboards and SQL queries as resources
Workspace Git Folders: Deploy bundles directly from workspace Git integration (experimental)
Add workspace: host: https://... to target definition
Deployed from wrong Git branch in prod target
Grant permissions via Databricks workspace admin
Notebook path in job definition is incorrect

Run databricks bundle bind resource or delete and redeploy
Service principal lacks permissions to resource
Use --force to override (not recommended in prod)
Variable referenced in YAML but not declared
Verify notebook exists in notebooks/ and path is relative

l: 20. Quick Reference: From Concept to Deployment
p: Minimal DAB Project (10 minutes to first deploy)
Databricks Asset Bundles enforce a GitOps, infrastructure-as-code approach to Databricks. Master these layers:
Declarative YAML: Define resources once; deploy to any environment
Environment Abstraction: Same code, different configurations via targets
Parameterization: Bundle variables (deploy-time) flow to job parameters (run-time)
Idempotent Deployments: Safe, repeatable, trackable via Git
CI/CD Integration: Automate promotions dev → staging → prod
This mental model unlocks reproducible, scalable, enterprise-grade Databricks deployments.
Open-source storage framework that brings ACID transactions to data lakes
Built on top of Parquet files with a transaction log
Not a separate storage system—it's a layer on top of existing object stores (S3, ADLS, GCS, HDFS)
Provides table abstraction over data lake files
File format specification for storing data with ACID guarantees
Data files: Parquet files containing actual data
Transaction log: JSON files tracking all changes (the _delta_log directory)
Delta Table = Delta Format + APIs to read/write
Delta Lake is NOT a database—it's a storage layer
No separate compute engine required—works with Spark, Presto, Trino, Flink, etc.
ACID transactions + schema enforcement on data lakes
Be clear: Delta Lake doesn't replace data lakes—it enhances them
Combines data lake flexibility with warehouse reliability
Delta Lake specifically introduced by Databricks in 2019, open-sourced immediately
Delta Lake, Apache Iceberg, Apache Hudi
Bad data ingestion with no guarantees
No ACID Transactions in Data Lakes
Small file problem (millions of tiny files)
Durability: Once committed, guaranteed to persist
mergeSchema=true adds new columns, doesn't remove or change types
Type changes require explicit ALTER TABLE
Every write creates a new version:
Versions retained based on retention period (default: 30 days)
Time travel uses transaction log, not data file copies
DELETE/UPDATE not in-place—creates new Parquet files
Old files marked as removed in transaction log
Same table accessed by batch and streaming—no separate pipelines
OPTIMIZE doesn't run automatically (unless Auto-Optimize enabled)
VACUUM deletes physical files—time travel stops working for vacuumed versions
Minimum retention: 7 days (safety check to prevent breaking time travel)
Constraint violations fail the entire transaction
Not all SQL constraints supported (e.g., FOREIGN KEY not supported)
Single source of truth for table state
Build current list of active files
Checkpoint = snapshot of entire table state at version N
Checkpoints don't replace JSON files—both coexist
Contains all add actions (active files) at that version
Without checkpoints, reads get slower as versions grow
"Optimistic" means: assume no conflicts, check at commit time
Checks if anyone committed v6 already → No
Checks if anyone committed v6 already → Yes (Writer A did)
If conflict: Retry from latest version (v6)
If no conflict: Write as v7
NOT pessimistic locking (no table locks during write)
Retries are automatic, transparent to user
Two writes conflict if they modify the same data files
Writer A attempts commit to v6:
Writer B attempts commit to v6:
"Active files list" = files added but not removed in log
Atomic commit by successfully writing log file
Build active files list at that version
Build final list of active files
Multiple readers can read different versions simultaneously
Read checkpoint (active files at checkpoint version)
Replay transaction log from v0 to requested version
Data skipping: Skip files not matching query predicates
Example: SELECT * FROM table WHERE id = 500
Delta reads stats, skips files where max(id) < 500 or min(id) > 500
Only for first 32 columns by default
Critical for query performance—enables data skipping without reading files
Query: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE date = '2024-01-15'
Only reads files where '2024-01-15' falls in [min, max] range
Co-locates similar values in same files
Example: Z-order by date→ all records for same date mostly in same file
Forgetting to OPTIMIZE → small file problem
Mark old files as removed in log
Not Z-ordering frequently filtered columns → poor data skipping
Transaction log in _delta_log is the single source of truth
VACUUM before retention period → breaks time travel

l: 2. Delta Lake Transaction Log & ACID Implementation

p: What it is: Ordered record of every transaction ever performed on a Delta table. Stored in _delta_log/ subdirectory.
Single source of truth for table state
JSON files: One per transaction (version), named with 20-digit zero-padded version number
CRC files: Checksum for JSON integrity validation
Checkpoint files: Aggregated state snapshots every N commits (default: 10)
_last_checkpoint: Metadata file pointing to latest checkpoint
Content: Single transaction's actions encoded as newline-delimited JSON.
Example: Creating a table with 2 files
Schema, partition columns, table properties, table ID
When created: After JSON commit file is written.
Content: Checksum of the JSON file.
Validation: On read, Delta recomputes JSON checksum and compares with CRC. Mismatch = corrupted transaction log.
Note: Not always present in cloud storage (S3, ADLS). Delta handles gracefully.
Purpose: Avoid replaying entire log history. Aggregate all table state up to version N.
When created: Every 10 commits by default (configurable via delta.checkpointInterval).
Structure: Parquet file containing all active add actions, latest metaData, and protocol.
All add actions for current table files
No remove, commitInfo(not needed for state reconstruction)
Multi-part checkpoints: For large tables, checkpoint split into multiple files:
Purpose: Quick discovery of latest checkpoint.
Content: JSON with checkpoint version and file count.
Usage: Readers start here to find checkpoint, then replay subsequent JSON commits.
Mechanism: Optimistic concurrency control + atomic file operations.
Writer reads latest version from log
Performs operation (e.g., writes new Parquet files)
Creates JSON commit file for version N+1
Attempts atomic write (PUT-if-absent in S3, conditional create in ADLS/HDFS)
If write fails: Another writer committed first. Retry with conflict resolution.
Key: JSON file write is atomic. Either version N exists or doesn't—no partial state.
Result: Both succeed (append is commutative) or one retries. No data loss, no partial commits.
Guarantee: Readers see complete snapshot at version N. Never see partial transaction.
Reader lists _delta_log/, finds latest version (or checkpoint)
Constructs file list from add actions at that version
Concurrent writes to version N+1 invisible until reader explicitly refreshes
Behavior: Second transaction detects conflict (overlapping predicate/partition), retries.
One retries, checks for logical conflicts
Transaction 2 reads N+1, detects logical conflict, retries as version N+2
Mechanism: Write-ahead log (Delta Log) committed before data visible.
Write new Parquet files to table directory
Only after JSON commit succeeds, transaction visible
Guarantee: If JSON commit exists, data files exist. If system crashes before JSON write, data files ignored (orphaned).
Cleanup: Orphaned files removed by VACUUM command.
Rule: Write schema must match existing table schema. Type mismatches or missing columns rejected.
Enforcement at: Write time, before Parquet files written.
Behavior: Add new columns, compatible type widening.
Type widening (e.g., int → long, float → double)
Drop columns (use ALTER TABLE DROP COLUMN)
Old data files: Retain old schema. Delta fills missing age with null on read.
Usage: Overwrite specific partitions while preserving schema and other partitions.
Delta Log: Adds remove actions for old 2023-01-02 files, add actions for new file.
Purpose: Allow column renames, drops, type changes without rewriting data.
none(default): Physical column names must match schema
name: Use field IDs, allow renames
id: Full column mapping with IDs
Delta Log: Schema updated, but Parquet files unchanged (field ID mapping used).
Create JSON commit with add actions
Key: isBlindAppend=true means no reads required, conflict-free.
Read phase: Scan files matching WHERE clause (using stats)
Rewrite phase: Rewrite affected files with updated rows
Commit phase: Add remove for old files, add for new files
Optimization: If predicate matches entire file, skipped (no rewrite). If matches no rows, skipped.
Best case: Partition pruning + Z-ordering reduce files scanned
Worst case: Full table scan if no partition/stats pruning
Two modes: Copy-on-Write(default) vs. Deletion Vectors(Delta 2.0+).
Cost: Proportional to data rewritten (even if deleting 1 row).
Binary RoaringBitmap with deleted row indices (e.g., [1] for row index 1).
Commit add action with deletionVector metadata—no remove
Compaction: OPTIMIZE merges DVs into rewritten files.
Copy-on-Write: Large deletes, infrequent deletes, already rewriting
dataChange=false: No new data, only metadata
DVs: Small deletes (<10% of file), frequent deletes
Generate deletion vector (RoaringBitmap) marking deleted row positions
pathOrInlineDv: DV file path or inline bitmap
Read behavior: Readers load DV, skip deleted rows.
Result: DV files removed, data files rewritten without deleted rows.
What: Bitmap index marking deleted rows. No file rewrite.
Process: Combines UPDATE, INSERT, DELETE in single transaction.
Match phase: Join source with target using ON condition
Commit phase: Atomic commit with mixed add/ remove actions
Log replay mechanism: How readers construct table state from JSON + checkpoints
Conflict resolution: Write-write conflicts, retry logic
File-level operations: No row-level deletes in Parquet—always file rewrites (or DVs)
Checkpoint usage: Why needed, when created, how reduces read latency
Schema evolution pitfalls: mergeSchema vs. overwriteSchema, backward compatibility
Deletion Vectors: Trade-offs vs. copy-on-write, when to optimize
ACID guarantees: Atomicity via file atomicity, isolation via versioning, durability via WAL
Checkpoint lag: If checkpoints disabled, readers replay 1000s of commits—slow reads
Small files problem: Frequent appends create many small files—use OPTIMIZE
DV accumulation: Many deletes create many DV files—run OPTIMIZE periodically
Schema evolution without mergeSchema: Fails silently if schema mismatch not caught
Concurrent overwrites: Two mode(overwrite) writers can conflict—use replaceWhere for partitions
Know JSON actions: add, remove, metaData, protocol, txn, cdc, domainMetadata
Explain checkpoint necessity: "Avoids O(N) log replay for readers"
Articulate DV benefits: "Efficient small deletes, deferred file rewrites, compaction required"
Describe conflict detection: "Optimistic concurrency—writers check overlapping predicates/partitions on retry"
Schema evolution rules: "Add columns, type widening allowed; drop/incompatible changes require explicit ALTER TABLE"
Identity columns auto-generate unique, monotonically increasing values
Introduced in Delta Lake 2.3.0 / DBR 11.3 LTS
Identity values are NOT gapless (gaps occur after failures, MERGE operations)
Identity column cannot be part of PARTITION BY
Cannot manually INSERT into GENERATED ALWAYS columns
Identity state stored in Delta table metadata
Values computed from expressions based on other columns
Computed at write time, stored physically (not virtual)
Useful for partitioning, indexing, data quality
Generated columns are computed at WRITE time (not read time)
Values are physically stored in data files
Common use case: partition pruning with derived date columns
Schema evolution compatible - can add generated columns via ALTER TABLE

l: 2. Reading Delta Format vs Delta Table

p: Table registered in Hive metastore or Unity Catalog
Metadata includes table name, schema, location, properties
Direct read from file path (no metastore entry)
Access underlying Delta log and data files
Useful for external tables, ad-hoc analysis
Delta Table = Delta Format + metastore metadata
Both use the same underlying format
Path-based reads bypass metastore, useful for data recovery
Delta Format can be read by non-Databricks Spark with Delta Lake library
Scenario: Update customer records, overwriting old values
Scenario: Track historical changes with effective dates
MERGE creates a single transaction version
Each record in target matched at most once (no duplicates)
Order of clauses matters: WHEN MATCHED before WHEN NOT MATCHED
Can have multiple WHEN MATCHED clauses with different conditions
MERGE INTO requires target to be Delta table
History does NOT show data-level changes (use CDF for that)
Creates new version in transaction log
Does NOT delete data files (VACUUM needed for cleanup)
Metadata points to files from target version
Old versions remain accessible until VACUUM
Cannot restore if target version VACUUMed
Cannot time travel beyond VACUUMed versions
Data files not referenced by any version within retention
Files referenced by versions within retention
Long-running queries reading old versions can fail during VACUUM
Permanently delete data files not required by recent versions
VACUUM runs in two phases: identify files, delete files
Clones can have different properties, schema evolution
Copies transaction log AND data files
Creating table variants with different properties
References same data files as source
REPLACE TABLE with CLONE syntax overwrites target
Shallow clones become "dangling" if source VACUUMed
Cannot enable CDF retroactively for past versions
CDF useful for CDC, incremental processing, audit logs
Adds new large files to transaction log
Compact small files into larger files
Marks old small files as removed
Collects min/max stats per file per column
Low-to-medium cardinality better than very high
Order matters: most selective column first
Reduce data scanning for filtered queries
Stores stats in transaction log ( add action)
Z-ORDER incompatible with partitioning on same columns
Z-ORDER is a one-time operation (must re-run after new writes)
Automatic incremental clustering (no manual OPTIMIZE needed)
Key Differences: Z-ORDER vs Liquid Clustering
Optimizes both read and write performance
Key difference: DLT infers dependency graph and handles orchestration. You declare what, not how.
DLT is built on Spark Structured Streaming fundamentals, enabling:
Critical insight: Streaming tables process each record once (assuming append-only source). Materialized views compute full state on each trigger.
Create Update: DLT analyzes code, discovers tables/views, builds DAG
Initialize: First run processes all historical data (full refresh)
Incremental Updates: Subsequent runs process only new/changed data
Not officially guaranteed: Exactly how DLT decides when to do full vs incremental refresh for materialized views depends on cost-based optimizer (varies by version).
Bronze → Silver → Gold pattern fits naturally:
Bronze: Raw ingestion via streaming tables with minimal validation
Silver: Cleaned, deduplicated tables with Expectations; mix of streaming tables and MVs
Gold: Aggregated/curated tables; typically MVs for performance
Interview note: Views are cheaper because they don't persist; use them for intermediate transformations.
Key insight: Streaming tables ≠ always running. They're triggered (continuous mode or scheduled); they maintain checkpoints to track processed data.
Managed (default): DLT owns storage location; dropped when table dropped
Unmanaged: You specify location; survives table drop
Interview note: Unity Catalog integration prefers managed tables for governance.
DLT auto-infers schema on first run (if not explicitly provided). Evolution:
Additive: New columns appended to schema (safe)
Restrictive: Column removal or type change requires manual intervention
DLT parses all dlt.read() calls to build dependency graph. Circular references cause CircularDependencyError.
Lineage tracking: DLT UI shows data flow. Event log contains flow_definition entries with input/output relationships.
storage: Root path for output tables + checkpoints + event logs
configuration: Spark configs (applied to all clusters)
continuous vs development vs production modes (mutually exclusive scheduling)
Interview note: Development mode speeds iteration; always validate in production mode before deploying.
Continuous: Cluster always running, processes data as it arrives
Triggered: Cluster starts only on schedule or manual trigger
Cost/latency tradeoff: Continuous = lower latency but constant DBU burn.
Best for aggregations, joins; not I/O-bound operations
When NOT to use Photon: Data extraction, lightweight ingestion, single-node Python code.
Auto Loader is the streaming source for cloud storage with built-in:
Schema inference: Samples first 50GB or 1000 files (whichever limit crossed first). Stores inferred schema in _schemas/ directory.
Interview insight: Streaming ingestion is stateful; batch is stateless. State corruption is the #1 streaming failure mode.
Streaming tables without watermarks process all data; with watermarking:
Watermarks only affect stateful operations(windows, joins). For append-only ingestion, watermarks have no effect.
Key difference: Python allows for complex logic, loops, conditionals; SQL is pure declarative.

For stateless operations (filters, selects), all table types are inherently incremental. For stateful operations (aggregations, joins), only streaming tables guarantee true incremental processing on classic compute.
Serverless compute(as of 2025): Materialized views get incremental refresh via cost-based optimizer.
Joins: Streaming table + streaming table requires watermarks. Streaming + static is safe.
Spark Structured Streaming models streams as unbounded tables with micro-batches:
Each micro-batch executes as a mini-Spark job
Fault tolerance via Write-Ahead Log (WAL) and checkpoints
Exactly-once semantics for deterministic sinks (Delta, databases with idempotent writes)
DLT abstracts: You declare a streaming table; DLT manages checkpoints, triggers, micro-batch size.
DLT does not expose processing-time directly; you work with event-time via withWatermark().
Idempotent producer: Auto Loader deduplicates based on file path + offset
Transactional sink: Delta Lake ACID guarantees
Checkpointing: Track processed offsets; resume from last checkpoint
Critical caveat: Exactly-once is per-partition for Kafka/message queues. DLT + Auto Loader guarantees exactly-once per file.
EXPECT(default): Log violations; write valid + invalid records
EXPECT_OR_FAIL: Fail entire pipeline on violation
Use expect_all_or_drop, expect_all_or_fail for grouped actions.
Event log stores expectation results in details:flow_progress.data_quality.expectations:
Important: apply_as_deletes applies at row level; apply_as_truncates clears entire table.
DLT automatically deduplicates out-of-order updates using sequence_by column:
Non-monotonic sequences: If sequence_by values jump backward (clock skew, late-arriving updates), DLT ignores the out-of-sequence record.
DLT writes to Delta tables, inheriting ACID guarantees:
Atomicity: Entire table version succeeds or fails
Isolation: Snapshot isolation; concurrent readers see consistent snapshot
DLT does not automatically call OPTIMIZE. Manual maintenance required:
Z-ordering clusters data by columns for faster pruning.
Critical: Cannot vacuum data referenced by time-travel queries. Retention period protects concurrent readers.
Enforcement: Strict mode; new columns rejected
Evolution: New columns appended (default in DLT)
Limitation: DLT tables read-only within DLT. MERGE requires raw Spark SQL outside DLT or within spark.sql().
DLT builds DAG from dlt.read() calls:
Execution order: bronze → silver → gold (automatically scheduled).
DLT pipelines are isolated. To depend on tables from other pipelines:
Not natively supported: DLT does not expose cross-pipeline dependency tracking. Use Databricks Workflows for multi-pipeline orchestration.
DLT validates DAG at pipeline startup. Circular refs cause immediate failure:
Every pipeline writes events to storage_location/_event_log(Delta format, incremental).
flow_progress: Execution metrics (rows, duration, data quality)
UI shows visual DAG. Event log contains:
flow_definition.input_datasets: Table(s) this table reads from
Streaming tables: Always incremental (only process new data).
Materialized views on serverless: Automatically incremental refresh (cost-based optimizer).
Materialized views on classic compute: Full recompute by default (unless you manually write incremental logic with MERGE).
Benchmark: 6.5x throughput improvement and 85% lower latency with incremental MVs on serverless (200B rows).
Partition pruning: Queries filter out partitions (faster)
Incremental ingestion: Auto Loader discovers new partitions only
Filter early: Reduce join input size
Broadcast small tables: Use broadcast() hint for tables <2GB
Avoid self-joins: Reframe logic to eliminate
For stateful streaming (aggregations, joins with windows), enable RocksDB:
Serverless automatically manages state store; classic compute requires manual configuration.
Materialized views: No explicit control; DLT decides
DLT tables automatically reside in Unity Catalog (if workspace enabled). Ownership and permissions:
Every table has an owner (user, service principal, or group). Owner can grant/revoke privileges:
Row-level security: Dynamic views with current_user():
Column-level security: Column masking via SQL UDF (not native to DLT, requires wrapper function).
Use Databricks Secrets API (not environment variables):
Strategy: Single codebase, different configs per environment.
Integration testing: Deploy test pipeline to staging; validate outputs.
Scenario: Historical data source added; need to reprocess last 2 years.
Approach 3: External orchestration Use Databricks Workflows to trigger multiple DLT pipeline runs with different parameters (not natively supported in DLT itself).
Problem: Source schema changes unexpectedly; pipeline breaks.
Auto Loader rescue column(capture unexpected fields):
Challenge: Pipeline failure mid-run causes duplicate writes. Solution: Make transformations idempotent.
Symptom: Pipeline halts; error message references checkpoint.
Restart pipeline (triggers full reprocess of streaming table)
Monitor for duplicates if logic is not idempotent
Problem: Window joins or large aggregations consume excessive state store memory.
Reduce window size or retention period:
DLT: Table-to-table dependencies; ideal for pure data pipeline orchestration
Workflows: Task orchestration; SQL queries, Python scripts, shell commands; more flexible
Use DLT for ETL pipelines. Use Workflows for orchestrating heterogeneous tasks (DLT pipeline + Notebook + SQL query + API call).
DLT: Native Databricks; simpler; automatic retry, monitoring, state management
Airflow: Open-source; more flexible; requires manual Databricks hook configuration
DLT is not a replacement for Airflow; different abstraction levels.
DLT: Batch + stream unified; managed by Databricks
Kafka Streams / Flink: Lower-level stream processing; more control, steeper ops burden
DLT is higher-level; preferred for lakehouse pipelines.
Scenario: Ingest real-time e-commerce transactions, clean, aggregate hourly revenue.
Windowing/groupBy automatically handles lateness with watermarks
Scenario: DLT pipeline fails with "Cannot cast StringType to IntegerType" error.
Check event log: Query event_log() for update_status = 'FAILED', read error details
Examine source data: Sample raw table, identify rows with unexpected types
Add debugging expectations: Log data quality metrics before transformation
Use development mode: Faster iteration for troubleshooting
Extract problematic step: Run in separate notebook for interactive debugging
Scenario: Source system adds new column; existing pipeline breaks.
Root cause: Explicit schema definition is too strict.
Scenario: CEO demands real-time dashboard; cost is high.
Recommendation: Triggered pipeline with 5-minute schedule; achieves real-time for most business use cases at 1/5 the cost.
Scenario: Track customer attribute changes over time; maintain full history.
Checkpoints are incremental: Streaming tables store processed offsets; recovery resumes from last offset
Exactly-once is per-partition: Kafka/message queues guarantee exactly-once per partition; Auto Loader per file
Materialized views are deterministic: Same input always produces same output; safe to recompute fully
Expectations are real-time: Metrics logged as data passes through; not post-hoc validation
DLT infers streaming vs batch: If source is streaming (readStream), table is streaming; else, it's a materialized view
State is locality-sensitive: Large state stores benefit from RocksDB; serverless auto-manages
Idempotency: Streaming + append-only = duplicates on restart
Circular deps: Will be caught immediately; design tables bottom-up
Checkpoint corruption: Manual recovery required; plan for it
Schema drift: Auto Loader rescue column is your friend
Over-specifying schema: Avoid explicit schemas in streaming ingestion; use inference + evolution
Stateful ops without watermarks: Windows/joins will backlog indefinitely without watermarks
Confusing EXPECT variants: EXPECT (logs), EXPECT_OR_DROP (silent removal), EXPECT_OR_FAIL (hard stop)
Latency vs Cost: Streaming continuous (low latency, high cost) vs triggered (higher latency, lower cost)
Incremental vs Determinism: Streaming tables are incremental but require idempotent logic; MVs are deterministic but expensive
Strictness vs Flexibility: Early schema enforcement prevents bad data; late schema enforcement (rescue columns) allows drift discovery
Complexity vs Automation: DLT abstracts away (simpler, less control); Workflows/Spark jobs expose (more control, more work)
Spark Declarative Pipelines(Apache Spark 4.1+): Databricks contributing DLT to open-source Spark
Serverless Incremental MVs: 6.5x throughput improvement, 85% latency reduction (200B-row benchmark)
RocksDB state management: Default for stateful ops; automatically tuned on serverless
Photon Acceleration: 2-4x speedup; ~ 2x DBU cost; skip for I/O-bound workloads
Unity Catalog: All DLT tables eligible for row/column security
Event log querying: event_log(table(...)) syntax enables centralized monitoring

DLT is a declarative ETL framework built on Spark Structured Streaming. You declare tables; DLT handles DAG construction, orchestration, state management, and failure recovery. Streaming tables are incremental; materialized views deterministic. Expectations enforce quality in real-time. APPLY CHANGES handles CDC (SCD1/2) natively. Checkpoints enable exactly-once semantics. Event logs provide deep observability. Biggest pitfall: assuming idempotency; design for it. Trade-offs are latency vs cost, complexity vs control. Master checkpoints, expectations, and the streaming-batch unification; you'll ace the interview.

SQL (Structured Query Language) is the standard language for managing relational databases. PostgreSQL is an advanced, open-source relational database management system (RDBMS) that implements SQL standards with extensive features like JSON support, full-text search, and advanced indexing.
Advanced indexing (B-tree, Hash, GiST, GIN, BRIN, SP-GiST)
Foreign Data Wrappers for external data access
The relational model organizes data into tables (relations) with rows (tuples) and columns (attributes). Each table has:
Primary Key: Uniquely identifies each row
Foreign Key: References a primary key in another table
A DBMS is software that manages database creation, modification, and access. PostgreSQL provides:
Retrieves data from the database without modification.
Defines the structure of the database and its objects.
Manages transactions and ensures data consistency.
The SELECT statement retrieves data from tables.
Groups rows by specified columns for aggregation.
Filters groups based on aggregate conditions (applied AFTER grouping).
Joins combine rows from multiple tables based on related columns.
Returns only matching rows from both tables.

Interview Question: What rows does INNER JOIN return if the join column contains NULL values? Answer: INNER JOIN does NOT return rows where the join condition is NULL, because NULL != NULL (NULL comparisons are always UNKNOWN). This is a common gotcha!
Returns all rows from left table + matching rows from right table (NULLs for non-matches).
Returns all rows from right table + matching rows from left table (NULLs for non-matches).
Returns all rows from both tables (NULLs where no match).
Cartesian product: combines every row from left table with every row from right table.
Joining a table to itself for hierarchical or comparative data.
Independent queries executed once, returning result to outer query.
Subqueries that reference columns from outer query; executed once per outer row.
Window functions perform calculations over a set of rows (a "window") without collapsing rows like GROUP BY.

l: Interview Question: Window Functions vs GROUP BY

p: CTEs (WITH clauses) create named temporary result sets for better readability and recursion.
For hierarchical data (organization structure, bill of materials, etc.).

Atomicity: Transaction is "all or nothing" - either all changes commit or all rollback. Consistency: Database moves from one valid state to another. Isolation: Concurrent transactions don't interfere with each other. Durability: Committed data survives system failures.
Nested rollback points within a transaction.
PostgreSQL implements MVCC (Multi-Version Concurrency Control) with 4 isolation levels:

l: 1. Read Uncommitted (Not explicitly supported in PostgreSQL)
p: Allows reading uncommitted changes from other transactions (dirty reads). PostgreSQL treats this as Read Committed.
Each statement sees committed data as of statement start. Prevents dirty reads but allows non-repeatable reads.
Transaction sees consistent snapshot from transaction start. Prevents non-repeatable reads but allows phantom reads (new rows appearing).
Highest isolation level. Transactions behave as if executed sequentially (no concurrency anomalies).
When two transactions wait for each other's locks.
Functions return a value and can be used in queries.
Procedures execute operations without returning values (though they can have OUT parameters).
Triggers execute automatically in response to database events (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE).
Views are virtual tables created from queries; they don't store data.
Ensures atomicity: all column values are atomic (indivisible).
Eliminates partial dependencies: non-key attributes must depend on the entire primary key (not just part of it).
Eliminates transitive dependencies: non-key attributes must depend directly on the primary key, not through other non-key attributes.
Stricter than 3NF: every determinant must be a candidate key.
Understanding query execution plans is critical for optimization.
PostgreSQL provides powerful full-text search capabilities for efficient text querying.

l: Connecting to Azure Database for PostgreSQL

p: Be ready for tricky NULL handling questions
CTEs & Recursive Queries- Clean code for hierarchical data
Explain execution plans using EXPLAIN ANALYZE
Indexing- Choose right types, monitor usage, avoid premature optimization
Joins- Understand NULL handling, duplicate keys, performance implications
Know when to use window functions vs GROUP BY
Practice complex JOINs with NULL values
Query Optimization- Use EXPLAIN ANALYZE, identify bottlenecks
Stored Procedures- Encapsulate business logic, improve security
Subqueries- Know when to use correlated vs non-correlated
This comprehensive guide covers expert-level SQL concepts for PostgreSQL interviews. Key takeaways:
This guide should serve as your complete reference for SQL interviews. The key is deep understanding, not rote memorization.
Transactions- ACID properties and isolation levels
Understand isolation levels and transaction handling
Window Functions- Powerful for ranking, running totals, comparisons
